BE11:18am

Anyway, here's Goldman to say it again.

BE11:18am

While ITV remains better positioned structurally than peers owing to its exposure to content, we see near term risk/reward as more balanced following recent outperformance (ITV is the only TV stock up 9% YTD vs. peers -16% on average). Near-term upside from the World Cup is already priced in, in our view, while additional investments could be announced at the upcoming strategy refresh.

11:18 am
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 172.50, down 4.95 (-2.79%), High: 177.40, Low: 170.70, Volume: 6.32m
Otter Hello internet friends.
Ethelred @VV75 Hope springs eternal
Otter I too would like to hear about our yacht painting friends at the GYG
BE11:19am

We believe recent performance already prices in the near-term upside from the World Cup (we revise our NAR for June/July to 18%/8% from 16%/3% although our FY NAR remains unchanged at -0.3% (consensus -0.4%) as we believe the near-term upgrade is more likely a pull forward of ad spend. Meanwhile, we believe the new CEO could announce additional investments at the strategy refresh at the 1H results.

BE11:19am

Longer term however, we believe ITV continues to be better positioned structurally than peers given its exposure to content (35% of revenue) making it a beneficiary of the rising value of content and therefore the most feasible M&A candidate in the TV space. We reduce our 2018E EPS modestly to reflect higher Broadcasting & Online opex. On 10.9x 2019E P/E, the stock no longer trades at a discount to TV peers which we view as fair given the growth outlook and risk around the strategy refresh.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

"feasible M&A candidate" ... .super.

BE11:20am

That's all part of a bigger media note that buys TF1 and Mediaset.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Someone's going to be left holding the bag there.

Soundbuy :)
Forester @MR Diamond I was a holder of GYD but after the last Zeus fiasco, I doubled checked which of my stocks were floated by them and sold on the spot!
BE11:24am

There's a very strong expectation that Fox will counter, but it has been slightly underbidding against expectations up to this point.

BE11:25am

Here's Credit Suisse

11:26 am
BE11:26am

In yesterday's statement Disney showed it was supportive of Fox's increased offer for Sky and was willing to take on increased debt to fund that offer. Fox has spent 18 months going through the UK regulatory process to acquire Sky and we don't believe 1400p is likely to be its final offer. This regulatory process is very close to ending with approval for the Fox bid based on the Secretary of State being minded to accept Fox's undertakings. Accordingly we raise our price target to 1600p which is 7% ahead of the closing price on 11th July 2017 and 8.5% ahead of Comcast's recommended offer of 1475p.

BE11:26am

Our price target of 1600p equates to 10.1x our 2020E EBITDA, which is in line with the media sector (ex-internet). It implies a FCF yield of 6% which is 12% lower than the media sector (ex-internet). The offer from Comcast at 1475p per share implies 9.4x 2020E EBITDA and 6.5% FCF
yield. The ultimate outcome of the rival bidding process between Fox and
Comcast remains difficult to see. It is likely to come down to the strategic
value of the asset to both parties and their respective financial capacity. As we have remarked before if Comcast is not successful in acquiring the Fox assets this could free up resources to focus its attention on Sky in an attempt to broaden further beyond the US market.

BE11:27am

And it's getting too rich for Macquarie's blood.

Ethelred @Kalkkaar previous interest from Softbank when ISAT was £8 a share.......
VV75 which never materialised..
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Counter offers from Fox and Comcast make it unlikely that Sky’s current price will be materially beaten in a bidding war with waning momentum, in our view. Sky retains strong fundamentals with a fair value around 1300p. Our existing target price of 1450p is based on a premium offer and Fox’s latest bid potentially signals a cooling of competitive tension.

Ethelred @VV75 You don't say......
BE11:28am

They go to neutral from buy.

undefined
11:29 am
BE11:29am

I see the Inmarsat rampers are among us.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 545.60, up 17 (+3.22%), High: 551.80, Low: 536.80, Volume: 839.47k
BW6 @BE anything on the overreaction of the ASOS trading update?
BE11:31am

..... haven't heard anything specific to today, though the usual stuff we've reported remains true.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

........ as in, management has its feet in the fire to deliver and there are a few potential buyers out there -- including potentially Dish Network if Charlie wants to play smart on the Takeover Panel rules.

BE11:32am

Berenberg sets out the argument this morning.

kalkaar tvm (ref ISAT)
kalkaar @Ethelred - yes no smoke without fire.. one hopes
BE11:34am

Given Echostar’s actions to date and the lack of any obvious material
synergies between the two companies, it is somewhat debatable whether any combination between Echostar and Inmarsat will be consummated.
However, given the confidence of Inmarsat’s board that 532p significantly
undervalues the company on a standalone basis, we expect some pressure
from shareholders for management to back up this claim with some positive communication.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Shareholders need to be careful with what they wish for, however; those who have followed the stock over recent years have witnessed the results of what can happen if management looks through rose-tinted glasses. Visibility and timing of any value crystallisation remains limited, in our view, and our price target suggests downside to the current share price. That said, we do expect management to be pressured by shareholders into providing more details on the pathway to medium-term value creation, which could reassure investors for now. We also believe ongoing M&A speculation will likely provide a floor to the share price in the coming months. We thus reiterate our Hold rating.

VV75 hope is delayed disappointment
BE11:34am

Clearly Inmarsat shares have been boosted by Echostar’s interest and are now comfortably off the multi-year lows they were trading at prior to the
announcement on 8 June. With ongoing speculation likely to continue, and
perhaps a now more bullish management stance (as described above), we
expect this premium could continue over the coming months. M&A aside,
however, we do not believe the shares offer value at the current levels.
Upside could come from new exceptional revenues or continued Ligado
payments, but with no certainty on these we think neither are suitable
reasons to put fresh money into the shares today. The stronger US dollar is the main driver of both our estimate changes and small price target update.

anonymous254 @MRDiamond, seems odd, given apparent visibility over revenues "because superyacht refits are booked typically three to 18 months in advance"
kalkaar "consummated" - now there's a word you don't hear very often in broker notes lol
BE11:36am

And good luck to anyone chasing theories around a quick payback via Softbank or whoever. We've not heard anything to support such theories, though we have heard from a lot of stale bulls.

11:35 am
undefined

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 5,840, down 660 (-10.15%), High: 6,184, Low: 5,736, Volume: 1.04m
VV75 try to stay objective as usualI
Stateless *@MrD
BE11:38am

The news, in case you missed is, is that Asos has missed Q3 expectations by a mile and guided its full-year sales target to the bottom of the range.

BE11:39am

Margins, they say, will compensate at the full year.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

As you'd hope when the shares are, what, 25x ebitda?

kalkaar VV75 - fair comment - wherever price action leads one must take head and follow..
BE11:40am

Here's Morgan Stanley

BE11:40am

Guidance for revenue growth is maintained at 25-30% range, but guiding towards lower end. PBT expected to be in-line with current consensus (£101m). All other guidance unchanged. Q4 requires c.26% growth to meet bottom end of guidance. The company said July has started strongly, so they believe this could be achieved. Additional one-off promotional activity is planned for the next quarter, which should drive higher growth, but it is a 2-month period, characterized by discounting. We currently forecast full-year group revenue growth of 28% to £2,455m (consensus £2,462m), GP margin +101bps to 49.6% and PBT of £101 (4.1% margin), in line with consensus (£101m, 4.1% margin).

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Q3 constant FX sales growth of 21% is a miss versus consensus at 25% and only a very minor re-acceleration from an already weak 2Q at +19% and against easier comps in Q3.

BE11:41am

That's ...... pretty mediocre.

BE11:42am

Now, the counterpoint here is that management don't want gangbusters sales growth.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Managing margin is much more important. Here's Santander:

BE11:43am

P3 was a complex trading period across global apparel
markets with adverse weather, a relatively early Easter,
heightened inventories and promotional fatigue, and for ecommerce,
the introduction of GDPR. Over and above this, ASOS
is undergoing infrastructure upgrades which needs managing in
order to avoid change risk as in H&M’s case (Hold, SEK 133.0/sh).
With the above in mind, we are supportive of management
prioritizing full price sales growth and managing demand
around infrastructure change, while a pick-up in P4 growth
(underpinning the reiteration of FY sales growth) suggests that
some of the P3 trading anomalies were of a temporary
nature.

Grouchmonkey Dart Group seems another case of market overreaction, but the other way. Good figs admittedly but.....
Mr Diamond GYG plc - should they have warned earlier, rather than wait until 6 weeks after half year period end? They must have known if project wins were coming in at the rate required to meet expectations, or not as the case suggests
VV75 I've seen too many pi's lose their shirt on vague rumors who then cling to that hope when all signs say otherwise.
BE11:44am

But against that, you have guidance of a 4% medium-long term EBIT margin

Oh, there was a request somewhere back there for Capita.

Excel Developer Trump thinks (and will claim) he scored victory at Nato
11:59 am
BE11:59am

More flogging stuff, more contract stuff.

BE12:00pm

Price looks okay on the former.

BE12:00pm

Here's Jefferies.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Capita has announced the divestment of ParkingEye for £235m. This is likely to be well ahead of consensus expectations as the 16.8x EV/EBITA exit multiple is more than double the 7.1x Capita paid for the business in October 2013. Consequently, the group has raised its target for non-core asset disposal proceeds in 2018 from £300m to more than £400m.
In addition, the group has announced a £109m/6 year contract to manage the administration, processing and support for all primary school national curriculum assessment tests in England. The contract will contribute 0.4% to organic revenue growth and, as the customer is central government, we suspect may be lower than the group’s 10% + target margin.

BE12:01pm

Isn't ParkingEye the company that's often referenced in those stories about NHS car parks charging folk £20 a day?

Pharma Trump had a point. European defence spending is dire.(disclaimer: Trump appears to be a truly awful person, but is proving to be a better than average politician)
Excel Developer @Pharma: yep
Pharma @BE that's the one. Number plate recognition, where is you mistake O/0 or 1/I they still go after you for penalty charges.
Pseudonym The 4% idea is daft though. If the EU spent 2% on defence it'd be outstripping Russian by 4 or 5 times even with their silly levels.
BE12:03pm

Numis also buyers in a news wrap.

#REF! Capita (and Serco) getting paid to take the flak for the public sector's dirty work since 1998...
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

In the last five weeks, Capita has announced a number of contract wins and extensions, and two notable disposals. We regard this as evidence that its client relationships are far from broken, and that it has the capacity to reduce its financial leverage more rapidly than the market currently forecasts. The disposals are dilutive (we have reduced our 2019 EPS from 14.1p to 13.1p), but we now forecast Dec-18 net debt/EBITDA of 1.1x. We re-iterate our BUY and 250p price target.
